Iterations and Matrix Multiplication

Welcome to the notebook with the exercises for the second session. You’re well on your way to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!

If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Exercise #1 - HDFS User Interface
In this exercise, you will create a second SSH tunnel to connect to the HDFS UI. In this UI, you can see the details of the distributed storage system that your current cluster is using.

To create a new SSH tunnel, follow the next steps:

1. On the `Google Cloud Shell` used to execute this Zeppelin instance, click the `+` sign to **Add cloud shell session**.

2. To create the tunnel, enter the following command: 
`gcloud compute ssh --project data-castle-bravo --zone us-central1-a --ssh-flag="-L 9870:localhost:9870" de-training-<user-name>-m` (be sure to replace `<user-name>` with your personal username ID)

3. Click the `Web Preview` icon. 

4. From the list that appears, select `Change port`.

5. Enter the new port number: 9870.

6. Select `Change and Preview`.

msg.data:
Exercise #1 - HDFS User Interface

In this exercise, you will create a second SSH tunnel to connect to the HDFS UI. In this UI, you can see the details of the distributed storage system that your current cluster is using.

To create a new SSH tunnel, follow the next steps:

  1. On the Google Cloud Shell used to execute this Zeppelin instance, click the + sign to Add cloud shell session.

  2. To create the tunnel, enter the following command:
    gcloud compute ssh --project data-castle-bravo --zone us-central1-a --ssh-flag="-L 9870:localhost:9870" de-training-<user-name>-m (be sure to replace <user-name> with your personal username ID)

  3. Click the Web Preview icon.

  4. From the list that appears, select Change port.

  5. Enter the new port number: 9870.

  6. Select Change and Preview.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore the UI to answer the following questions:

+ How many nodes does your cluster have?
+ How much memory has been assigned to the cluster?
+ How many nodes are active, and how many are dead?
+ How much storage capacity is remaining?
+ What are the cluster metrics?

**TIP:** If you would like to know the available memory or review your cluster’s capacities, look at the HDFS UI again after the executions.

msg.data:
Explore the UI to answer the following questions:

  • How many nodes does your cluster have?
  • How much memory has been assigned to the cluster?
  • How many nodes are active, and how many are dead?
  • How much storage capacity is remaining?
  • What are the cluster metrics?

TIP: If you would like to know the available memory or review your cluster’s capacities, look at the HDFS UI again after the executions.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Sockets for other UIs 
As you may have noticed by know, the [SSH tunnel we created for Zeppelin](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/accessing/cluster-web-interfaces#create_an_ssh_tunnel) is exposed on port 8080 of your cluster's master node. A [short list of the UIs](https://console.cloud.google.com/dataproc/jobs?project=data-castle-bravo) you may find available in this cluster are:

+ **Zeppelin**: `localhost:8080`
+ **HDFS NameNode**: `localhost:9870`

### Exposing HDFS to Other Nodes
To look at each individual node, you will need to create an SSH tunnel to that particular instance and expose the pertinent port as follows:
`gcloud compute ssh --project data-castle-bravo --zone us-central1-a --ssh-flag="-L 9870:localhost:9870" de-training-<user-name>-m`

Be sure to replace `<user-name>` with your personal username ID.

msg.data:
Sockets for other UIs

As you may have noticed by know, the SSH tunnel we created for Zeppelin is exposed on port 8080 of your cluster’s master node. A short list of the UIs you may find available in this cluster are:

  • Zeppelin: localhost:8080
  • HDFS NameNode: localhost:9870

Exposing HDFS to Other Nodes

To look at each individual node, you will need to create an SSH tunnel to that particular instance and expose the pertinent port as follows:
gcloud compute ssh --project data-castle-bravo --zone us-central1-a --ssh-flag="-L 9870:localhost:9870" de-training-<user-name>-m

Be sure to replace <user-name> with your personal username ID.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Exercise #2 - Matrix Multiplication
In this exercise, we explore the `Matrix` data type. All `Matrix` implementations in Spark are another abstraction of `RDD`s.
 
**Note**: All that you need to know about `Matrix` multiplication will be provided to you in this notebook. 

Prioritize researching the functions that belong to `DataFrames` or `DataSets`, I/O Functions, or Spark Core in general over any `Matrix` method or function you wish to use. During the next three weeks you will gain knowledge about tools and information to better optimize this operation.

**HINT:** As you gain more knowledge throughout the course, we recommend that you revisit these exercises to see how you can optimize the code.

First, import the data structures you will be using during the session with the following command:

msg.data:
Exercise #2 - Matrix Multiplication

In this exercise, we explore the Matrix data type. All Matrix implementations in Spark are another abstraction of RDDs.

Note: All that you need to know about Matrix multiplication will be provided to you in this notebook.

Prioritize researching the functions that belong to DataFrames or DataSets, I/O Functions, or Spark Core in general over any Matrix method or function you wish to use. During the next three weeks you will gain knowledge about tools and information to better optimize this operation.

HINT: As you gain more knowledge throughout the course, we recommend that you revisit these exercises to see how you can optimize the code.

First, import the data structures you will be using during the session with the following command:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.mllib.linalg import Matrices
from pyspark.mllib.linalg.distributed import BlockMatrix, CoordinateMatrix, MatrixEntry

%md
#### Create dataset
The most straight forward implementation for a matrix multiplication is using a `BlockMatrix`. The [documentation](https://spark.apache.org/docs/2.3.0/mllib-data-types.html#blockmatrix) describes this type of matrix as a **Distributed Matrix** backed by an `RDD` of `MatrixBlock`s.

A `MatrixBlock` is a tuple of `((Int, Int), Matrix)`. In this context, `(Int, Int)` is the (row, column) position of the block while `Matrix` is the sub-matrix at the given index with size `rowsPerBlock` x `colsPerBlock`

msg.data:
Create dataset

The most straight forward implementation for a matrix multiplication is using a BlockMatrix. The documentation describes this type of matrix as a Distributed Matrix backed by an RDD of MatrixBlocks.

A MatrixBlock is a tuple of ((Int, Int), Matrix). In this context, (Int, Int) is the (row, column) position of the block while Matrix is the sub-matrix at the given index with size rowsPerBlock x colsPerBlock

paragraphs.text: %md Below you'll find the `MatrixEntry` sequences containing the location and value of each element in all matrices (for the PySpark version we use tuples rather than `MatrixEntry` objects and we create `Dataframes` rather than `RDD`s) Your job is to create four `RDD`s, each using one of the provided sequences:

msg.data:
Below you’ll find the MatrixEntry sequences containing the location and value of each element in all matrices (for the PySpark version we use tuples rather than MatrixEntry objects and we create Dataframes rather than RDDs)

Your job is to create four RDDs, each using one of the provided sequences:

paragraphs.text:
val greenEntries = Seq(MatrixEntry(0, 0, 21), MatrixEntry(1, 0, 23), MatrixEntry(0, 1, 22), MatrixEntry(1, 1, 24))
val blueEntries = Seq(MatrixEntry(0, 0, 11), MatrixEntry(1, 0, 13), MatrixEntry(0, 1, 12), MatrixEntry(1, 1, 14))
val orangeEntries = Seq(MatrixEntry(0, 0, 0.4), MatrixEntry(1, 0, 0.2), MatrixEntry(0, 1, 0.3), MatrixEntry(1, 1, 0.1))
val brownEntries = Seq(MatrixEntry(0, 0, 4), MatrixEntry(1, 0, 2), MatrixEntry(0, 1, 3), MatrixEntry(1, 1, 1))

%md
**TIP:** You can create an `RDD` with Spark using this command:  `sc.parallelize()`

msg.data: TIP: You can create an RDD with Spark using this command: sc.parallelize()

paragraphs.text:
%md 
**TIP:** Remember that you can create a Data Frame with Spark using this command: `spark.createDataFrame()`

msg.data: TIP: Remember that you can create a Data Frame with Spark using this command: spark.createDataFrame()

paragraphs.text:
%md

#### BlockMatrix creation function
The easiest path to create a `BlockMatrix` is by first creating a `CoordinateMatrix`, and then using the `toMatrixBlock()` method.

In Scala, in order to create a `CoordinateMatrix` you need an `RDD` of `MatrixEntry`.

In Python, you can use `DataFrames` that are consistent with the tuple  `((Int, Int), Matrix)` format (you did this in the previous step)

msg.data:
BlockMatrix creation function

The easiest path to create a BlockMatrix is by first creating a CoordinateMatrix, and then using the toMatrixBlock() method.

In Scala, in order to create a CoordinateMatrix you need an RDD of MatrixEntry.

In Python, you can use DataFrames that are consistent with the tuple ((Int, Int), Matrix) format (you did this in the previous step)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a function called `createBlockMatrix` where you input a matrix in `Dataset` format and create a `BlockMatrix` from an RDD using the class `CoordinateMatrix` and the method `toMatrixBlock()` mentioned before.

msg.data: Create a function called createBlockMatrix where you input a matrix in Dataset format and create a BlockMatrix from an RDD using the class CoordinateMatrix and the method toMatrixBlock() mentioned before.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now apply the function `createBlockMatrix` to generate the four block matrices, following the naming convention `<color>Matrix`:

msg.data: Now apply the function createBlockMatrix to generate the four block matrices, following the naming convention <color>Matrix:

paragraphs.text: %md **TIP**: You may need to turn the `Dataframe` into an `RDD` using the `.rdd.map(tuple)` method invocation.

msg.data: TIP: You may need to turn the Dataframe into an RDD using the .rdd.map(tuple) method invocation.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
Now that all matrices are `BlockMatrices`, use the method `.multiply(<block_matrix>)` to perform the multiplication of the four matrices.
We can verify that we built the matrices correctly by printing the result of `toLocalMatrix()`

msg.data:
Now that all matrices are BlockMatrices, use the method .multiply(<block_matrix>) to perform the multiplication of the four matrices.
We can verify that we built the matrices correctly by printing the result of toLocalMatrix()

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note:** we are converting the `BlockMatrix` back to `CoordinateMatrix` for writing purposes.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Exercise #3 - Matrix Multiplication

Find the result of the multiplication of each squared matrix. 

This statement requires you to square each matrix, and then multiply them together. So we need to do something as follows:

```
greenMatrix^2 * blueMatrix^2 * orangeMatrix^2 * brownMatrix^2
```

You have already implemented a multiplication, now implement a function for exponents.

You can name your function `matrixPower`. This function should receive an integer (non-zero and positive) and a `BlockMatrix` as arguments.

**NOTE:**: This is the perfect opportinuty to practice recursion and your functional programming skills.

msg.data:
Exercise #3 - Matrix Multiplication

Find the result of the multiplication of each squared matrix.

This statement requires you to square each matrix, and then multiply them together. So we need to do something as follows:

greenMatrix^2 * blueMatrix^2 * orangeMatrix^2 * brownMatrix^2

You have already implemented a multiplication, now implement a function for exponents.

You can name your function matrixPower. This function should receive an integer (non-zero and positive) and a BlockMatrix as arguments.

NOTE:: This is the perfect opportinuty to practice recursion and your functional programming skills.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Before going further, test this with the green matrix. Compare the result of your function with the succesive multiplication for a few exponents.

msg.data: Before going further, test this with the green matrix. Compare the result of your function with the succesive multiplication for a few exponents.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Finally, use the `matrixPower` function along with the `multiply(<block_matrix>)` method to calculate *the sequential multiplication of each squared matrix*.

msg.data: Finally, use the matrixPower function along with the multiply(<block_matrix>) method to calculate the sequential multiplication of each squared matrix.

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Congratulations for completing the exercises!**

Do spend some time thinking of other possible improvements for your code on your own time, such as how to support fractional exponents in `powerMatrix`, what the right output for an exponent `0` should be, and other types of inputs.
